data.title: Fix opengl rendertargets
data.body:
This is a fix to make rendertarget work as expected in OpenGL. Here is the gist of it:
- There is no need to create one FBO per rendertarget; we can simply swap attachments when we call GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTargets; also this paves the way to multiple rendertargets support
- The default color buffer needs to be reset before frame swap (iOSGameView.Present) to ensure the one that might be created in the RenderTarget constructor  doesn't interfere.

Tested on Infinite Flight (iOS), we use rendertargets quite extensively.

Not sure why so many files got included in this pull request; let me know if this is a problem.

data.title: Update Windows 8 Quickstart
data.body:
Time to update the Windows 8 quickstart guide:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/wiki/MonoGame-on-Windows-8-Quick-Start

It refers to develop3d which is no longer relevant. Plus, it's probably in need of some updating.

data.title: Android ResetClientBounds
Investigate WP8 MediaPlayer Performance
data.body:
This issue stems from the discussion in PR #1109.

Using MediaEngine to play music for games is an explicitly stated usage scenario in WP8:

> "Play in-game background audio in apps that use native code, such as a game soundtrack."
> 
> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windowsphone/develop/jj207074(v=vs.105).aspx

This requires we remove MediaEngineCreateFlags.AudioOnly as it is unsupported on WP8.  This puts MediaEngine into "frame server mode" which supports both video and audio playback.

This brought up performance concerns:

> We could use frame server mode, but that would have a 
> serious impact on performance. My Lumia 920 can't keep up 
> drawing the frames without any music played, so it's a real 
> thing. That's why I decided to use MediaElement, as it had 
> the least impact on performance according to what I saw.

We need to investigate the performance impact with and without music playback on WP8.

It would be best if we performed the same test running an WP7 XNA app on the same WP8 hardware to verify the difference.

If there is a noticeable performance issue with MediaEngine one alternative to try is MediaElement.  See PR #1337 for the implementation.

data.title: TypeInitializationException Fix for WP8 MediaPlayer
data.body:
WP8's construction of media player was failing for two reasons.

1) AudioOnly flag/mode is not supported on WP8: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windowsphone/develop/jj681688(v=vs.105).aspx

2) CoreWindow.GetForCurrentThread() on WP8 always returns NULL on WP8.

data.title: Windows Phone 8: Content.Load<SoundEffect> crashes with unhandled TypeInitializationException
data.body:
Any attempt to load a SoundEffect from a .xnb file on Windows Phone 8 crashes with an unhandled TypeInitializationException.

In thread http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/432974 SlyGamer indicated it may be do with the the compression and suggested setting this to Best in the XNA Content project. However I cannot get the sound effect to load with any of the available compression settings.

data.title: #1376 Adding some defensiveness to the OpenAl sound setup
data.body: Added some comments where appropriate, moved the hardware init code into its own method, added a state flag to know when the sound hardware was setup or not, and added more aggressive handling of hardware setup errors. See issue #1376.

data.title: Make SpriteFont data members public (but not mutable)
data.body:
Related to issue #1391, I think it would be beneficial to diverge from MS's interface for SpriteFont and make the glyph data public, but immutable. At present in XNA SpriteFont's data members are entirely private for no good reason, which means that if you want to do custom text rendering you have to throw out _everything_ and rebuild it all from scratch. 

In practice, it's possible to get at the data members and use them for your own purposes because they're just rectangles and floats with a pretty sensical layout. Of course, doing this isn't portable, so having to support reflecting against both Microsoft and MonoGame's internal SpriteFont data structures is pretty awful. 

At present, my solution for this was to make the Glyph instances in SpriteFont accessible so that it's usable in these scenarios. This let me do my text rendering using existing SpriteFont assets on both platforms:

https://github.com/kevingadd/Fracture/blob/master/Squared/RenderLib/Evil.cs#L262

An alternative method would be to make the MonoGame SpriteFont implement a new interface of some kind that exposes methods for this. I'd be happy with that too, because then you can detect it with 'is'/'as' and not need #ifdefs.

data.title: Platform-specific internals should be public
data.body:
This is probably controversial, but I think all the platform-specific monogame internals should, where it makes sense, be publicly accessible - either as public readonly fields, or public getters, or whatever.

To give a specific example, right now using MonoGame on PSM has required me to aggressively fork the code because _all_ the PSM-specific handles were private. This made it impossible to call PSM-specific APIs where required, especially in cases where what I needed to do was impossible to express through the XNA API.

I understand that this might create a risk of people writing games that are no longer 'Just XNA', but I think now that XNA is officially dead and buried this is less of a concern - especially since MonoGame can be run natively on windows. Perhaps you could set it up so a warning is generated by each line of code using these internals from outside?

data.title: Cleanup of documentation for SoundEffectInstance and misc code cleanup.
data.body: Cleanup of documentation for SoundEffectInstance. Removed unnecessary hold on the parent SoundEffect reference. Removed a duplicate initialization of the source buffer. Changed the use of Math.exp in the pitch conversion code to use Math.pow so that it can be understood better.

data.title: IsMouseVisible + Window.IsBorderless
data.body:
This pull request has the following changes:
- IsMouseVisible fix on WinDX
- IsMouseVisible fix on WinGL
- Window.IsBorderless on WinDX
- Window.IsBorderless on WinGL
- Window.IsBorderless on Linux

data.title: Fix Matrix::Transpose.
data.body:
The current Transpose will break if `matrix` and `result` are the same value. This bug is apparent when working with the FarseerPhysicsXNA engine.

Pretty easy fix, just store the result elsewhere, then assign `result` at the end.

data.title: EffectData is always null
data.body: Could not find a place where set_EffectData was being called, therefore audioData is always null.

data.title: Update docs for SoundEffectInstance
data.body:
per another long discussion regarding the pitch of a sound effect, we need to change the Xna to OpenAL pitch conversion to better reflect the formula known for doing this conversion, and then to document it. This is the excerpt from the conversation:

/\* XNA sets pitch bounds to [-1.0f, 1.0f], each end being one octave.
- OpenAL's AL_PITCH boundaries are (0.0f, INF).
  *
- Consider the function f(x) = 2 ^ x
- The domain is (-INF, INF) and the range is (0, INF).
  *
- 0.0f is the original pitch for XNA, 1.0f is the original pitch for OpenAL.
- Note that f(0) = 1, f(1) = 2, f(-1) = 0.5, and so on.
- XNA's pitch values are on the domain, OpenAL's are on the range.
- Remember: the XNA limit is arbitrarily between two octaves on the domain.
  *
- To convert, we just plug XNA pitch into f(x).
  */
  if (xnaPitch < -1.0f || xnaPitch > 1.0f)
  {
  throw new Exception("XNA PITCH MUST BE WITHIN [-1.0f, 1.0f]!");
  }
  return (float) Math.Pow(2, xnaPitch);

data.title: Readme.MD update - will exposing information from develop branch now.
Replaced NSTimer with CADisplayLink.
data.body:
Note: This is the same as https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1317 but updated for the branch migration.

This PR implements part of the discussion that started in #1030 but severely got off topic.

Apple's documentation states that an NSTimer's effective resolution is limited to 50-100ms. Using a CADisplayLink is a preferred way to implement a high resolution timer, as we can see resolutions as fast as ~16-17ms.

Depending on the project there may or may not be a performance gain from this.

data.title: First working SpriteFontDescription .xnb written
data.body:
Note: This is https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1322 resubmitted into the correct branch.

This pull request includes a couple of things.

First, SpriteFontDescription is working! 

At the moment it only outputs the texture in an uncompressed format. I left it this way for now because I was unsure of how we'd select the compression for the font. Will it be via a property similar to how the Texture2DProcessor works? Either way, since Compression is already implemented, this is a rather quick fix.

At the moment, using generics in the pipeline was not working. Long story short, we are doing a dictionary lookup for readers and writers, but at runtime we can't use this lookup against an instance of this generic type. As far as the dictionary lookup is concerned, List and List aren't the same thing. I came up with a solution, but am unsure if it's the best one.

There are still some improvements to implement, but this is a good starting point.

data.title: Quick fix for iOS to compile
data.body: Same as #1377 but for develop branch

data.title: Template And Installer Fixes
data.body:
Simple template fixes and additions.
- Fixed syntax error #ifdef.
- Added Windows desktop DirectX template.
- Added Windows desktop DirectX to installer script.

data.title: Fix seeking past DSP/RPC tables for complex sounds.
data.body:
This is a renewal of my original XactSound pull request, but for the new develop branch.

For complex sounds (!= 0x02) we currently seek too far, and eventually you'll get a bizarrely huge value that'll cause us to read past the end of the stream.

This fixes the issue, as we're supposed to account for the extraDataLen value itself when seeking past the extra data.

I've got some DSP/RPC table reading in my branch too, but it's a bit ugly at the moment. For now, this will at least fix crashes for anyone that happens to be porting their stuff over.

data.title: Add MSADPCM WaveBank support
data.body:
This is a renewal of my original MSADPCM pull request, but for the new develop branch.

This adds the ability to parse WaveBanks that are compressed with ADPCM wavedata. This is a cross-platform and fully functional solution, but there is a concern with possible hanging when loading large banks.

If we want to fix the load hang, we'll need to find a way to stream decoded wavedata to sources that play the WaveBank sounds.

Real talk though: I've been using this for Codename lolno, and I gave this to the developer of Gateways, and nobody's commented on hanging (for us it's a couple seconds total). I imagine if someone has a WaveBank that's 150+MB it'll get ugly, but this is at least a start.

data.title: iOS render states + build fixes
data.body: We (Flying Development Studio / Infinite Flight) are in the process of syncing our MonoGame branch to the latest and greatest (we used an old fork from september 2011 that we heavily customized for our needs). A lot of things seem to work right off the box and i'll be sending pull requests for what we fix along the way in order to get Infinite Flight to work with MonoGame 3.X.

data.title: Quick fix for iOS to compile
data.body: Just a quickie. Somehow that using went missing from #1334

data.title: OpenAl problem
data.body:
I'm having a issue with OpenAl. When i run my project in the output appears:
Could not open AL device - OpenAL Error: InvalidDevice

This is the stack trace:
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object. ---> System.Exception: 
  --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.OpenALSoundController.Update()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGamePlatform.BeforeUpdate(GameTime gameTime)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.DoUpdate(GameTime gameTime)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Tick()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGameWindow.OnUpdateFrame(Object sender, FrameEventArgs e)
  at System.EventHandler`1.Invoke(Object sender, TEventArgs e)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.OnUpdateFrame(FrameEventArgs e)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.OnUpdateFrameInternal(FrameEventArgs e)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.RaiseUpdateFrame(Stopwatch update_watch, Double& next_update, FrameEventArgs update_args)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.DispatchUpdateAndRenderFrame(Object sender, EventArgs e)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.Run(Double updates_per_second, Double frames_per_second)
  at OpenTK.GameWindow.Run(Double updateRate)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.OpenTKGamePlatform.RunLoop()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run(GameRunBehavior runBehavior)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run()
  at escaladeWin.Program.Main() in Program.cs:line 21

What i did to try solve the problem?
1 - Uninstall OpenAl 
2 - Uninstall MonoGame
3 - Check the references for the project
4 - Search in google. I found this issue https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/823, but i think this is not my problem.
5 - I searched, here, in git and on codeplex. Again, only the issue 823 on git.

*My project does not contains any kind of music.

Any idea how to solve this?

data.title: Use OpenAL Soft on Android in place of SoundPool
data.body:
OpenAL Soft provides a software-based OpenAL implementation.  The Android version uses OpenSL beneath the hood.

Android port is available at https://github.com/AerialX/openal-soft-android
It appears to not have been updated since Feb 2012.

Official OpenAL page is at http://kcat.strangesoft.net/openal.html
Latest version is 1.15 released Dec 2012.

Suggest forking the Android port and merging the latest official release.

data.title: Support IMA4/ADPCM playback for SoundEffect
data.body:
OpenAL-Soft for Android supports IMA4/ADPCM playback by decoding to PCM on demand in the BufferNeeded callback.  We need to do the same on iOS as OpenAL does not support IMA4/ADPCM playback.

If required, do the same on Mac OS X and Linux where required to support IMA4/ADPCM playback.

Check PS Vita playback support.

Windows-based XAudio2 platforms should already support MS-ADPCM.  Check Windows GL playback support.

data.title: Improve Android threaded loading
data.body:
Without any support in Android for threaded OpenGL contexts, the usual method of creating GL resources on a secondary GL context is not available to us on Android.  The GL context cannot even be shifted to the worker thread temporarily.  The work-around is to load the data from file on a worker thread, but pass control back to the main thread for GL calls.  This can only be done when the main thread is ready.  Currently the main thread polls for waiting work before and after calls to Game.Update and Draw.

With the synchronous nature of the standard XNA ContentManager, only one asset can ever be waiting to be created on the main thread.  That asset must be fully loaded before the next asset is loaded from file.

One solution would require the addition of an asynchronous ContentManager.Load method that would allow multiple assets to be loaded and queued to make more use of the time in the main thread by allocating multiple GL resources each time the main thread checks for pending work.

data.title: Windows installer should check previous versions are uninstalled
data.body: We have had a few issues caused by installing the released version over existing beta installations.  The installer should check that previous versions are uninstalled before allowing to proceed with the installation.  If possible, the installer should launch the uninstaller for the installed version.

data.title: Add support for using ETC1 textures on OpenGL platforms
data.body:
Add a SupportsEtcCompression property to GraphicsCapabilities that returns true if the GL extensions report ETC1 is supported.

Enable loading of ETC1 data into textures.

data.title: Add support for using PVRTC textures on OpenGL platforms
data.body:
Add a SupportsPvrCompression property to GraphicsCapabilities that returns true if the GL extensions report PVRTC is supported.

Enable loading of PVRTC data into textures.
